intro: Cupaniopsis sylvatica, commonly known as the silky oak, is a member of the family Euphorbiaceae and is native to eastern Australia. It is a small to medium-sized tree that typically grows to a height of 5–15 meters, featuring a broad, spreading canopy. The leaves are alternate, simple, and often have a silvery or greyish underside, giving the plant its common name. Its flowers are unisexual and clustered in dense inflorescences, with both male and female flowers present on the same plant. The fruit is a capsule that splits open to release small, dry seeds.
